metadata.case_name: State of Assam v. Ranga Mahammad

facts.text: State of Assam consists of three Sessions Divisions: Upper Assam Districts (Jorhat HQ), Lower Assam Districts (Gauhati HQ), Cachar Districts (Silchar HQ).

Government of Assam with concurrence of High Court made Assam Judicial Service (Senior) Rules. Rule 5: Chief Justice fills Registrar post (Art. 229); other posts filled by Government in consultation with High Court; not more than 1/3 direct recruitment; others by promotion.
Senior Judicial Service: Grade I (4 posts: Registrar + 3 District Judges); Grade II (Additional District Judges).

On December 6, 1962, Chief Justice appointed A. Rahman (District Judge, Gauhati) as Registrar; recommended D.N. Sarma (Additional District Sessions Judge) as District Judge Gauhati; D.C. Sharma as Additional in Sarma's place. Accepted by Government.
Medhi, District Judge, retiring creating vacancy. Telephone conversation: Finance Minister suggested C. Choudhury (Joint Secretary Legal Dept.) for officiation; Chief Justice willing.

January 5, 1963: Chief Justice D.O. letter - Rules do not permit; no vacancy for direct recruit from Bar (1/3 limit); Choudhury cannot be transferred from Legal Dept. to Judicial Service (Art. 233 requires Judicial Service or 7 yrs Advocate). Recommended N. Deka for promotion to Jorhat vacancy.
January 24, 1963: Minister's strong letter expressing amazement at change; not transfer but judicial experience; constitutional provisions not invocable as Choudhury qualified.

February 7, 1963: Chief Justice - no non-cooperative attitude; enquire why Rahman not released; recommend B.N. Sarma as District Judge in Rahman's place; S.C. Barua transfer Cachar to Gauhati; D.N. Deka promotion to Jorhat.
June 22, 1963: Notification appointing D.N. Deka as District Judge, HQ Jorhat.
September 7, 1963: Govt. letter - cannot accept Barua transfer; propose transfer B.N. Sarma to Jorhat, Deka to Gauhati as Jorhat vacant for months.
Registrar reply: matter stale, High Court to reconsider.
January 22, 1964: Registrar - B.N. Sarma to Silchar, Barua to Jorhat, Deka to Gauhati.
February 19, 1964: Govt. final reply - recommendations not acceptable except Deka to Gauhati; B.N. Sarma transferred to Jorhat; Notifications issued transferring Deka to Gauhati and Sarma to Jorhat.

Ranga Mahammad filed two writ petitions in Assam High Court under Arts. 226/227 questioning Deka's jurisdiction at Jorhat (no consultation for appointment/posting at Gauhati) and Sarma's transfer to Jorhat.

High Court (Mehrotra CJ & Dutta J.): No consultation for Deka posting; transfer of Deka to Gauhati irregular (High Court power); Sarma transfer irregular. But no quo warranto as no wrongful occupation; petitions dismissed without costs.
Dutta J. separate concurring judgment: scathing remarks on Govt. action as mala fide, ulterior motive.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 132 (interpretation of Arts. 233/235).
Govt. counter affidavit: acted within powers, consulted High Court.

legal_issues.text: Who is to order transfer of a District Judge - the State Government or the High Court?
Is the provision regarding consultation in Arts. 233 and 235 mandatory or directory and if the former, whether the High Court was in fact consulted?
Should the remarks of Mr. Justice Dutta about the State Government be expunged?

petitioner_arguments.text: The High Court was, in fact, consulted.
Alternatively, the power to transfer District Judges lies with the State Government and not with the High Court.
Expunction of remarks of Mr. Justice Dutta.

respondent_arguments.text: High Court alone could make transfers; not consulted before orders.

court_reasoning.text: Power to transfer District Judges vested in High Court under Art. 235 control over subordinate courts; Art. 233 'posting' means initial assignment on appointment/promotion, not transfer (by context with 'appointment' and 'promotion'; dictionary meanings; noscitur a sociis). Governor's power ceases after initial posting.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Posting' in Art. 233 bears second meaning: assign to a post/position, not station/transfer.

court_reasoning.text: High Court better suited for transfers due to intimate knowledge; policy of Constitution.
Consultation mandatory per Chandra Mohan v. UP; here consultation occurred before D.N. Deka promoted/posted.
No need for consultation on transfers as State Govt. has no power.
Remarks of Dutta J. not to be expunged; no impropriety though unnecessary; power extraordinary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court's stand vindicated; consultation entitled to highest regard.

holdings.text: Transfer of District Judges is within High Court's control under Art. 235, not Governor's power under Art. 233.
Consultation under Arts. 233/235 mandatory; here it was done for promotion/posting of D.N. Deka.
Remarks of Dutta J. not expunged.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal & Anr. v. Nripendranath Bagchi
precedents_cited.relevance: History of Arts. 233-237; High Court sole custodian of control except Governor's exclusive jurisdiction on appointment/posting/promotion of District Judges.
Consultation mandatory; vindicates High Court's stand on Choudhury.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Appointment/posting/promotion of District Judges by Governor in consultation with High Court (233); Control over subordinate courts including posting/promotion vested in High Court (235); interpreted to exclude transfers from Governor's power.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Judicial Service (Senior) Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Recruitment to Senior Judicial Service; consultation required; 1/3 direct recruitment limit.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's view that transfers of District Judges are High Court's prerogative under Art. 235, not State Government's; consultation was done for Deka's promotion/posting; declined to expunge Dutta J.'s remarks. Appeals seeking reversal of High Court's interpretation dismissed in substantial part.
outcome.relief_granted: None; High Court judgment affirmed on key points.

key_quotes.text: In Art. 233 the word posting clearly bears the second meaning. This word occurs in association with the words appointment and Promotion and takes its colour from them.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The High Court is better suited to make transfers than a Minister. For however well-meaning a Minister may be he can never possess the same intimate knowledge of the working of the judiciary.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reasoning for vesting transfer power in High Court.

key_quotes.text: Consultation loses all its meaning and becomes a mockery if what the High Court has to say is received with ill-grace or rejected out of hand. In such matters the opinion of the High Court is entitled to the highest regard.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: On importance of consultation and context for remarks.
